output.conclusion: By completing this course, you've gained a foundational understanding of game theory and its applications. You can now identify strategic situations, analyze potential outcomes, and make more informed decisions in various aspects of your life.
output.introduction: Welcome to Game Theory for Beginners! This course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts of game theory, a powerful tool for analyzing strategic interactions. We'll explore how individuals and organizations make decisions when their outcomes depend on the choices of others. No prior knowledge is required!

chapters.description: Introduction to the basic concepts of Game Theory. Definition of a game, players, strategies, and payoffs. Real-world examples of strategic interactions.
Overview of different types of games: cooperative vs. non-cooperative, simultaneous vs. sequential, zero-sum vs. non-zero-sum.
Learn how to represent games using normal form (matrix) and extensive form (game tree) representations.
Understanding dominant strategies and how to identify them. Examples of games with dominant strategies.
Introduction to the concept of Nash Equilibrium: a stable state where no player can benefit by unilaterally changing their strategy.
Methods for finding Nash Equilibria in simple games. Examples and practice problems.
A classic example of a game with a dominant strategy that leads to a suboptimal outcome. Discussion of cooperation vs. defection.
Exploring real-world applications of game theory in economics, politics, business, and everyday life.
Discussion of the assumptions and limitations of game theory. Introduction to behavioral game theory.
